data.title: IncompleteRead getting data from groups.io
data.body:
I've seen the error below in our Bitergian production instances where we are analyzing the group `cloudfoundry+cf-dev`

The error:
```
Error feeding ocean from groupsio (https://groups.io/g/cloudfoundry+cf-dev): ('Connection broken: IncompleteRead(49926748 bytes read)', IncompleteRead(49926748 bytes read))
```
How to reproduce:
* get a valid token for groups.io
* subscribe to the group at https://lists.cloudfoundry.org/g/cf-dev/ and get a token
* execute ```perceval groupsio cloudfoundry+cf-dev -t ***``` using the token

user_data.name: Luis Cañas-Díaz

data.title: [git] Include tags and branches information
data.body: This code enhances the git backend to include the names of tags and branches where a commit appears. Note that the performance of the backend is affected, 4 secs are now needed to parse 200 commits, against 1 sec that was required before.

comments_data.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/19933472/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/19933472)

Coverage decreased (-0.4%) to 96.663% when pulling **06f71da6f613a0230825fb603b63422cc78dac10 on valeriocos:add-tags-branches-info** into **ab2078f3a708c867b9b1912a9bd31daf38c974d3 on chaoss:master**.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/19935374/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/19935374)

Coverage increased (+0.01%) to 97.068% when pulling **9ee1c2ab3399db504c3d64609daf589dfa703151 on valeriocos:add-tags-branches-info** into **ab2078f3a708c867b9b1912a9bd31daf38c974d3 on chaoss:master**.

> I guess this doesn't work incrementally, does it?

No, it doesn't work incrementally.  

> Since this has a severe performance penalty, could it have an option to disable it when needed? 

I have just added a commit to make it optional

> No, it doesn't work incrementally.

I think it would be convenient to state that crystal clear in the documentation, since that is a major difference with the regular working of the backends.

> I have just added a commit to make it optional

Great! Thanks.

@valeriocos, why was this not merged?
Was it due to it not properly supporting increment?

user_data.name: Aniruddha Karajgi
user_data.bio: GSoC'19 @chaoss • Junior  at  BITS Pilani, Pilani Campus • B.E.  Computer Science • Data Science (Minor)

comments_data.body:
Hi @Polaris000 , it doesn't work incrementally and thus it is not really useful in production environments. However for one-shot analysis it works fine. If this case fits in your scenario feel free to reuse the code.

The problems with branches (and also tags) are:
- (i) they are pointers to commits and they can change at any moment (a merge, a rebase, etc.)
- (ii) the information retrieved by Perceval is just about commits, thus changes at branch level are not collected
- (iii) getting branch changes from Git is not trivial.
 
The solution GrimoireLab offers is to update the branch information for all commits stored in the ElasticSearch database for each enrichement phase. Please have a look at the [code](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/enriched/git.py#L762) and don't hesitate to write in case of any questions/doubts :)

comments_data.body:

Will ask in case of any queries.

data.title: [groupsio] Fix invalid value for 'limit' in subscriptions query
data.body:
The request to retrieve the list of groups a user is subscribed to was wrong. The parameter 'limit' was set wrongly to the user authentication data. This commit fixes that bug.

Backend version updated to 0.1.3.

comments_data.body:

data.title: [Question] how to use supybot backend
data.body:
Hi, I'm trying to get any data from `supybot` Perceval data source, but I always get 0 messages.
I've read the class documentation and tried many many different URLs and I'm unable to fetch anything.
For example, I'm trying to get data from `#zephyrproject` channel on `irc.freenode.net`server.
No luck, tried:
```
perceval supybot 'irc://irc.freenode.net/#zephyrproject' ircdir
perceval supybot 'irc://irc.freenode.net/zephyrproject/' ircdir
perceval supybot 'irc.freenode.net/#zephyrproject' ircdir
perceval supybot 'irc.freenode.net/zephyrproject/' ircdir
perceval supybot 'http://irc.freenode.net/#zephyrproject' ircdir
perceval supybot 'http://irc.freenode.net/zephyrproject/' ircdir
perceval supybot 'http://webchat.freenode.net/zephyrproject' ircdir
perceval supybot 'http://webchat.freenode.net/zephyrproject/' ircdir
perceval supybot 'http://webchat.freenode.net/#zephyrproject' ircdir
perceval supybot 'http://webchat.freenode.net' 'zephyrproject'
perceval supybot 'http://webchat.freenode.net' '#zephyrproject'
```
No idea what is wrong.
Always getting the response:
```
[2019-06-18 07:28:23,205] - Sir Perceval is on his quest.
[2019-06-18 07:28:23,206] - Fetching messages of 'irc://irc.freenode.net/#zephyrproject' from 1970-01-01 00:00:00+00:00
[2019-06-18 07:28:23,207] - Fetch process completed: 0 messages fetched
[2019-06-18 07:28:23,207] - Sir Perceval completed his quest.
```
I was trying to figure out things from [this file](https://buildmedia.readthedocs.org/media/pdf/perceval/latest/perceval.pdf) and the last argument is a directory to retrieve/store log files. Am I supposed to fetch that logs manually? And datasource works only then? If so, then how can I fetch those logs?

Documentation is not clear about for example protocol name: shoudl I put `irc://` or use `http(s)://`address. webchat.freenode.net is using captcha (HTTP client) - is grimoirelab Perceval trying to go around somehow, or is it using other access modes? Is it using some random/anonymous user?

Can you provide at least one working example of this data source? Or for every data source in general? If data source requires any username/password/API token/ssh public key etc - then it would be nice to have documentation describing how to get those credentials?

user_data.name: Łukasz Gryglicki
user_data.bio:
Senior Developer @cncf, @linuxfoundation, @kubernetes
Interested in Go, Kubernetes, Helm, C, Ruby, RoR, Python, Rust, SQL, JavaScript, PHP, C++, Assembly

organizations.description: Sustaining and integrating open source technologies to orchestrate containers as part of a microservices architecture

comments_data.body:
Supybot backend doesn't download anything. It only analyzes files from a local directory. You have to have your own process to download the archives or to provide them to Perceval.

Sorry if the documentation is not clear about it. The parameter `uri` is the value that will go in the `origin` field and it's needed to generate the unique identifier of each item (as in any other backend). The parameter `ircdir` is where supybot archives are available.
OK, thats clear - would be great to have that info in the docs.

comments_data.body:
The only way to get data from IRC channels (as far as I know) is to have something listening on those channels. Either you or the admins of the channel should have a user/bot listening there to get the data. Admins used to have that and `supybot` was the most common some years ago.

Supybot produces a specific output format. If data was generated by other bot, you will have to create something to translate from that format to supybot one, or to create a backend to parse that data.

data.title: [Question] trying to use groups backend
data.body:
Hi, I'm trying to use `Groups.io` Perceval backend.
The documentation says that I need `GitHub OAuth token` but groups.io doesn't have an option to login via GitHub. I've created an account on groups.io and it can only allow logging in via standard email/password pair or via Google or via Facebook. I've checked all groups.io setting and there is no way to create API token there and their documentation says: `Authentication to the API is performed via HTTP Basic Auth, using a token received from the login API call` [here](https://groups.io/api#authentication-1). SO this is totally unclear what token should I provide.
Next group name, then documentation only says `perceval: error: the following arguments are required: group_name`, what is this group name? I want to get data from zephyr project, what should I pass there?

Senior Developer @cncf, @linuxfoundation, @kubernetes

comments_data.body:
**Groups.io** is full of tricks. I've been working with it recently and it was hard to understand how to run it. 

To get a token you need to run the next command:
```
curl "https://api.groups.io/v1/login" -u 123456: -d "email=<your email address>&password=<your password>"
```
The user must be `123456`.

Next, you have to subscribe your user to the mailing lists you want to track.

Once you have that, to analyze those mailing lists in `groups.io`  under a different domain, you have to use the name of the group plus the name of the subgroup. Something like the next should work:
```
perceval groupsio -t <your_token> "zephyrproject+main"
```

Let me know if this worked for you. I'll update the documentation if that's the case.
Thanks a lot. Will let you know soon.

comments_data.body:
So the first part (token related) works, I've created the following bash script to get token value and then call Perceval:
```
#!/bin/bash
if [ ! -f "/etc/groupsio/token" ]
then
  echo "No saved groups.io token"
  echo -n "groups.io email/login: "
  read email
  echo -n "groups.io password: "
  read -s pass
  echo ""
  response=`curl -s "https://api.groups.io/v1/login" -u 123456: -d "email=${email}&password=${pass}"`
  token=`echo $response | jq '.token'`
else
  token=`cat /etc/groupsio/token`
fi
if ( [ -z "$token" ] || [ "$token" = "null" ] )
then
  echo "Cannot get token value, exiting"
  exit 1
fi
if [ ! -f "/etc/groupsio/token" ]
then
  echo $token > /etc/groupsio/token
fi
echo "Token: $token"
perceval groupsio -t "$token" "zephyrproject+main"
```

data.title: [groupsio] Fix description `api_token`
data.body: This code fixes the docstring of the `api_token` variable. Backend version has been changed accordingly: 0.1.4

data.title: [github] "Rate limit not initialized: 401 Client Error" when invoked from python script
data.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to fetch issues from a GitHub repository. I have perceval version 0.12.16. When I invoker perceval from the command line, I am able to fetch the issues.

However, when I try to get the issues through a python script, it fails. I downloaded [perceval_github_1.py](https://chaoss.github.io/grimoirelab-tutorial/perceval/scripts/perceval_github_1.py) and ran it and here's the error:

> Rate limit not initialized: 401 Client Error: Unauthorized for url: https://api.github.com/rate_limit
Rate limit not initialized: 401 Client Error: Unauthorized for url: https://api.github.com/rate_limit
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "perceval_github_1.py", line 24, in <module>
    for item in repo.fetch():
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/backend.py", line 160, in fetch
    self.client = self._init_client()
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/backends/core/github.py", line 237, in _init_client
    self.archive, from_archive)
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/backends/core/github.py", line 563, in __init__
    self._choose_best_api_token()
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/backends/core/github.py", line 862, in _choose_best_api_token
    self._update_current_rate_limit()
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/backends/core/github.py", line 907, in _update_current_rate_limit
    raise error
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/backends/core/github.py", line 899, in _update_current_rate_limit
    response = super().fetch(url)
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/client.py", line 132, in fetch
    response = self._fetch_from_remote(url, payload, headers, method, stream, verify)
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/client.py", line 173, in _fetch_from_remote
    raise e
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/perceval/client.py", line 168, in _fetch_from_remote
    response.raise_for_status()
  File "/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 940, in raise_for_status
    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 401 Client Error: Unauthorized for url: https://api.github.com/rate_limit

Can you please let me know how this can be fixed?

Thanks,
Vysali.

user_data.name: Shivashree Vysali V S
user_data.bio: Software Engineering | DevOps

comments_data.body:
Hi @svysali , thank you for using Perceval.

Please try to include the token in a list. One of the latest features added to the GitHub backend is the possiblity to pass a list of tokens, for instance:
``` 
backend = GitHub("chaoss", "grimoirelab-perceval", api_token=["token-1", "token-2"], archive=archive, sleep_for_rate=True)
```

Let us know if this solves your issue, otherwise please share your code.
Thanks!

Thank you @valeriocos. Once I changed the api_token to a list, I was able to retrieve the issues.
Thank you once again !

comments_data.body:
My fixed version is:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
#
# Copyright (C) 2015-2019 Bitergia
#
# This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
# it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
# the Free Software Foundation; either version 3 of the License, or
# (at your option) any later version.
#
# This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
# but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
# MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. See the
# GNU General Public License for more details.
#
# You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
# along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
# Foundation, 51 Franklin Street, Fifth Floor, Boston, MA 02110-1335, USA.
#
# Authors:
#     Valerio Cosentino <valcos@bitergia.com>
#

import json
import requests

OAUTH2_TOKEN = 'https://secure.meetup.com/oauth2/access'

def get_token(client_id, client_secret, redirect_uri, code):
    access_uri = "{}?client_id={}&client_secret={}&redirect_uri={}&code={}&grant_type=authorization_code".format(OAUTH2_TOKEN,
        client_id,
        client_secret,
        redirect_uri.strip("\""),
        code
    )
    headers = {
        'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded',
        'Accept': 'application/json'
    }
    r = requests.post(access_uri, headers=headers)
    r_json = r.json()
    print(json.dumps(r_json, sort_keys=True, indent=4))

def main():
    print("Access https://secure.meetup.com/meetup_api/oauth_consumers and create a consumer (if you don't have it)")
    print("Replace YOUR_CONSUMER_KEY and YOUR_CONSUMER_REDIRECT_URI with the correct info in the link below")
    print("https://secure.meetup.com/oauth2/authorize?client_id=YOUR_CONSUMER_KEY&response_type=code&redirect_uri=YOUR_CONSUMER_REDIRECT_URI")
    print("If everything goes OK, you will get a code as param of YOUR_CONSUMER_REDIRECT_URI, for instance: https://example.com/test?code=683f3ebe84bf867d2b8d591faa389ed5")
    print("Use this code, together with your client key, secret, redirect URI to get an access token")
    client_id = input('Enter your client key: ')
    client_secret = input('Enter your client secret: ')
    redirect_uri = input('Redirect URI: ')
    code = input('Code: ')
    print("***** ***** ***** *****")
    get_token(client_id, client_secret, redirect_uri, code)
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

comments_data.body: I would rather think about passing all stuff needed to generate `OAuth2` token (which is `key` and `redirect_uri`) generating code, then using all 4 items (key, secret, redirect_uri and code) to get a token. All of this should happen automatically, without the need to use any manual steps.  I can accept manual steps, even complex if they need to be done once, but if this is needed every hour then we need to automate this, otherwise `meetup` backend is unusable from shell scripts, cron jobs or Kubernetes.

comments_data.body:
@lukaszgryglicki I have been testing the use of the same oauth token on different days and with a battery of meetup groups (around 120). The token doesn't seem to expire, so I'm not sure the param `expires_in` is active. 

I also had a look at the [RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.2.2), from the description below , it may be possible that what we see it's the default value, which is finally ignored.
```
expires_in
         RECOMMENDED.  The lifetime in seconds of the access token.  For
         example, the value "3600" denotes that the access token will
         expire in one hour from the time the response was generated.
         If omitted, the authorization server SHOULD provide the
         expiration time via other means or document the default value.
```

If the assumptions above are correct, once the access token has been generated you can use it directly within the perceval backend (without the need of adding the logic to generate a new token).
Ok, I will try to generate another one and just use it, and then let you know. Thanks.

data.title: [Question] How to use discourse tokens?
data.body:
Suppose I want to get discourse data, I can do it tokenless via: `perceval discourse https://edgex.discourse.group`, but I expect to hit some rate limit or be banned by IP or whatever after some time.

The documentation says that I can use token.

I'm going to `https://edgex.discourse.group` site, create an account and then I want to create a token, but I don't see any option to create token there.
Can anybody (like backend author) point me to some instructions about how to create such a token?

Additionally:
-----------------------------
I suggest that every single data source (there are 29 currently) should have its own `example` section in the documentation, describing step-by-step how to get data from a single example source.
- This will make it a lot easier to use
- This will probably detect some bugs or outdated data sources (I've already detected meetup as outdated)
- This will make sure what specific parameters value should be (usually group, URL, resource, etc - it is never clear if we should put URL there, or project name uppercase/lowercase or some custom resource definition separated by hyphens or dots or whatever)
- Some additional parameters - like some data sources require at least 1 argument, other require two, etc (this will make it a lot clearer)
- Finally, many data sources use some authentication (API keys, tokens, usernames, passwords, SSH public keys and more). We should have a clear example of how to create them and then how to provide them (for example GitHub backend supports multiple tokens, I've implemented this myself).
------------------------------

comments_data.body:
> Suppose I want to get discourse data, I can do it tokenless via: `perceval discourse https://edgex.discourse.group`, but I expect to hit some rate limit or be banned by IP or whatever after some time.
> 
> The documentation says that I can use token.
> 
> I'm going to `https://edgex.discourse.group` site, create an account and then I want to create a token, but I don't see any option to create token there.
> Can anybody (like backend author) point me to some instructions about how to create such a token?

From[ Discourse documentation](https://docs.discourse.org/), under **Authentication** section:

```
To become authenticated you will need to create an API Key from the admin panel.
```

> ## Additionally:
> 
> I suggest that every single data source (there are 29 currently) should have its own `example` section in the documentation, describing step-by-step how to get data from a single example source.
> 
>     * This will make it a lot easier to use
> 
>     * This will probably detect some bugs or outdated data sources (I've already detected meetup as outdated)
> 
>     * This will make sure what specific parameters value should be (usually group, URL, resource, etc - it is never clear if we should put URL there, or project name uppercase/lowercase or some custom resource definition separated by hyphens or dots or whatever)
> 
>     * Some additional parameters - like some data sources require at least 1 argument, other require two, etc (this will make it a lot clearer)
> 

Most of these answers can be answered either reading the README file or running `perceval <backend> --help`, but of course, it needs a lot of improving.

>     * Finally, many data sources use some authentication (API keys, tokens, usernames, passwords, SSH public keys and more). We should have a clear example of how to create them and then how to provide them (for example GitHub backend supports multiple tokens, I've implemented this myself).

README file contain info for those backends where authentication methods are more complicated than others. I'd like to have a good manual for Perceval but so far, we couldn't find time to write it.

Thanks for your comments, anyway. We'll take into account and any help is always welcome.
Thanks for the info. I have no time to dive into it during the current or maybe even next week :(, but there was no admin panel at all AFAIR.

data.title: [Question] How to use meetup backend tokens?
data.body:
Hi, I'm wondering how to set up meetup token to be used for Perceval.
[Here](https://github.com/LF-Engineering/perceval-scripts#meetups) I'm trying to get Hyperledger meetup data using Perceval. I'm running this without tokens via: `perceval meetup --sleep-for-rate hyperledger`.
BTW: how should I set `--min-rate-to-sleep MIN_RATE_TO_SLEEP` parameter? I just want it to wait until rate limit is reset.
I've created a meetup account and then wanted to create OAuth token (just like in GitHub backend case).  But after reading [their documentation](https://www.meetup.com/meetup_api/auth) it only seems that `OAuth2` is supported, now see [this](https://www.meetup.com/meetup_api/auth/#oauth2). How can I create a single token string to be used by Perceval's `-t API_TOKEN` argument?
Would be great to have at least one example of how to use this and also other data sources. Most of the data sources that I've been working today are not documented and it is extremely hard to dive into details about what "group" is (an URL, an org name, a group/meetup name?), what is a token? How to create a token? This is a shared set of missing documentation data for almost all backends.

data.title: [jenkins] Support authenticated access
data.body:
This PR allows to fetch builds and jobs available via a Jenkins server, which requires authenticated access. The authentication supported are (user, password) and (user, API token)*.
Tests have been added accordingly.

This PR also extends the Perceval client, the `fetch` method now includes a new param `auth`, which allows to issue requests using basic authentication.

This PR replaces/addresses:
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/issues/432
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/pull/506
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/pull/433
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-sirmordred/issues/287

Information about how to retrieve a Jenkins API token is available at:
https://medium.com/@samratshaw/programmatically-retrieve-jenkins-rest-api-token-f2c3f0d69483

comments_data.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/24444752/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/24444752)

Coverage increased (+0.008%) to 97.085% when pulling **243724b2bb39e76c78b8446e530519b4081bde1f on valeriocos:suppor-auth-access-jenkins** into **399151ca0b579809b7b83bb619b4617eafee890d on chaoss:master**.

I'm not sure it's possible. To tackle this problem the PR provides support also to use tokens (instead of 
a password). As reported by the [doc](https://wiki.jenkins.io/display/JENKINS/Authenticating+scripted+clients), this should guarantee more safeness
```
API token is new since 1.426

Earlier versions of Jenkins require you to specify your real password, 
and it is only available when your security realm is password-based (for example, OpenID, 
Crowd and CAS plugins authenticate you without a password, so you simply 
don't have any password!) Specifying the real password is still supported after 1.426, 
but it is not recommended because the risk of revealing password, 
and the human tendency to reuse the same password in different places.
```

> I'm not sure it's possible. To tackle this problem the PR provides support also to use tokens (instead of
> a password). As reported by the [doc](https://wiki.jenkins.io/display/JENKINS/Authenticating+scripted+clients), this should guarantee more safeness
> 
> ```
> API token is new since 1.426
> 
> Earlier versions of Jenkins require you to specify your real password, 
> and it is only available when your security realm is password-based (for example, OpenID, 
> Crowd and CAS plugins authenticate you without a password, so you simply 
> don't have any password!) Specifying the real password is still supported after 1.426, 
> but it is not recommended because the risk of revealing password, 
> and the human tendency to reuse the same password in different places.
> ```

If that's the case, I suggest to only support tokens and avoid the user/password authentification.
As you prefer, I opened another PR here: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/pull/549 (to keep track of authentication with username and password)

data.title: [gitlab] Recalculate outdated list of merge requests
data.body:
If during the fetching process, a merge request was modified, the initial list of merge requests is outdated. Due to it, returned items will not be ordered, which can cause several problems when
an incremental retrieval is performed.

To avoid this problem, when the backend detects that an MR has been updated, the process will not be cancelled but it will request a new list, starting on the 'updated_on' field of the last item returned.

Backend version updated to 0.8.0.

data.title: Adapted the paths to work with Microsoft Windows too.
data.body: Before the files used the symbol "\" and other that this don't work with Microsoft. I've deleted this part to work with Posix and Windows systems.

comments_data.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/8523986/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/8523986)

Coverage decreased (-0.03%) to 84.664% when pulling **ecb2a820ceb5031767c11b261cf75bb0d84c404c on shongoku:windows** into **e5ca777599d1d791b1e0d7ea59bb22da99b68fc7 on grimoirelab:master**.

I still think we need to find a better way to include this feature. I was thinking if we merge this patch we will have a different behaviour in Windows with the directories where the cache is stored. For instance, in Windows, a URI like `https://example.org/project/repository` will be stored in a directory of name `example.org/project/repository` while in Unix, the cache will be stored in the subdirectory `repository`, under `project` and `example.org`.
I think we should have the same behaviour for both platforms.
The question is if you have two operating system, why do you have  the same URI? The main is the result and both are OK.

We now have a lot of conflicts here, and I'm not sure if you @sduenas came with a better solution for this... Any idea, anyone? Having this working in Windows would be rather interesting, from my point of view.

data.title: [logs] Add new log messages
data.body:
After a first revision of the Git backend module, a few new log messages has been added:

- It may be useful to distinguish between parsing a given git log file or it has to obtain that log file from a repository.

`logger.info("Fetching commits from the given log file %s", self.gitpath)`
`
logger.info("Log file not specified, retrieving from repository.")`

- As proposed, now a message informs if the repository is found locally or it has to be cloned first.

`logger.info("Git repository not found in %s", self.gitpath)`
`logger.info("Found Git repository in %s", self.gitpath)`


- Message    `logger.debug("Git %s repository cloned into %s",...` has been changed into `info` type, as this information may help to discriminate if the program has stuck in the cloning phase.

comments_data.body: ping @sduenas @jgbarah

I find it very interesting to have Perceval running in Windows. And as a temporary solution, using perceval-windows as a pip package, could be a good idea. However, a couple of comments:

* I'm not sure the change from `python3` to `python` is a good idea for non-Windows systems. Probably it is going to become a minor issues as python3 becomes the only python, but I see problems meanwhile, specially when people have both systems installed. I know with virtual environments this is a non-issue, but still... Is there no way of fixing this in Windows in some other way?
* With respect to the `perceval-windows` package in pip, which differences would it have? Because right now, `perceval` is mostly a source package.

I agree it would be great to have Perceval running on Windows. I don't see the solution you propose in this PR the best one, though. It will break how it works in Linux systems now.

One of the possible solutions that might work would be to install a different script depending the OS. A BAT file (or similar) for Windows and the Python file for Unix systems.

Some parts of the code should be adapted to support multi-platform. We can also have tests for both environments in Travis.

How about using the unspecified python version, checking if it is acceptable, then if not finding the highest version available on the system? I have not checked if the code below works.

https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/66210/how-can-i-have-more-than-one-possibility-in-a-scripts-shebang-line

#!/usr/bin/env python
import os, sys

pythons = [ '/usr/bin/python2.3','/usr/bin/python2.4', '/usr/bin/python2.5', '/usr/bin/python2.6', '/usr/bin/python2.7' ]
py = list(filter( os.path.isfile, pythons ))
if py:
  py = py.pop()
  thepy = int( py[-3:-2] + py[-1:] )
  mypy  = int( ''.join( map(str, sys.version_info[0:2]) ) )
  if thepy > mypy:
    print("moving versions to "+py)
    args = sys.argv
    args.insert( 0, sys.argv[0] )
    os.execv( py, args )

print("do normal stuff")

data.title: [backend] Add search terms
data.body:
This PR proposes to extend the metadata attributes by adding a new field (`search_terms`) with the purpose of simplifying query operations and avoding inspecting the data attribute. 

The search terms are included in a dict with the following shape:
```
        {
            'term-1': 'value-1',
            'term-2': 'value-2',
            'term-3': 'value-3',
        }
```
The search terms are added to the metadata information of each item in `search_terms` attribute. If search terms are not defined, `search_terms` will be set to `None`.

This new feature is showcased with the Jira backend.

data.title: [meetup] Pass oauth2 token via headers
data.body:
This PR tackles https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/issues/567.

The oauth2 token was passed as payload of the requests when issuing petitions to the Meetup API. This was causing a potential security leak for failing petitions, since the URL with the corresponding payload was fully exposed.

Now the token is passed through the headers, which are then sanitized before storing them to the archive.

Since API tokens have been decommissioned in favor of oauth2 token, API token support has been removed from the backend.

Tests have been changed accordingly.
Backend version is now 0.15.0.

data.title: [groupsio] Replace HTTP basic auth with cookies based auth
data.body:
This PR addresses #569. It replaces the previous authentication method with a cookies based one. This change is due to recent changes in the Groupsio API that will be effective at the end of September.
More info at: https://beta.groups.io/g/api/message/115

Now the backend accepts email and password (no the api_token anymore), they are used to call the login endpoint, which will set one or more cookies, and enable the other endpoints to work.
All requests performed by the backend are now handled via a session object, which automatically manages cookies.

Tests have been added accordingly.
Backend version is now 0.2.0

The script to list subscriptions has been updated, the new version is available at: https://gist.github.com/valeriocos/2e2231e17fd3052800303bf99bd0c7c4

data.title: Summary of results
data.body:
It will be awesome to have a summary with the results after each call to `fetch`.

The summary will keep the number of items read, generated, ignored or skipped; the log of the process; when the task started and when it finished; and probably some important notes, for example, like in Git when new branches are retrieved and others are deleted.

comments_data.body:
To get the results the backend should implement a method like `backend.result()`. This method will return the result of the last execution of the backend. It should return `None` when an execution is still running or no result has been produced yet.

Another option is to implement the method `backend.results()` to return all results produced by this backend. Maybe this can be implemented later if we think we really need it.

The result object should at least contain:

* total of items read from the source
* number of items generated
* number of items ignored or skipped
* max date among the items generated
* min date among the items generated
* max_offset of the items generated (when is available=
* min_offset of the items generated
* last items UUID returned by the backend
* notes or extra: each backend can add anything here, like in Git where we should know which new branches where retrieved, which branches where deleted, etc.

data.title: [perceval] Include summary of fetch executions
data.body:
This PR allows to calculate and return the summary of fetch executions. By default, it includes the last UUID generated, number of items fetched, skipped and their sum, plus the min, max and last updated_on times. Furthermore, for backends using offsets, the corresponding summary contains the last, min and max offsets retrieved. Finally, the summary also includes some extra fields, which can be used by any backend to include fetch-specific information.

The summary is available through the context manager class `BackendItemsGenerator`, which initializes a backend, performs the fetch operations (i.e., fetch or fetch_from_archive) and returns a summary of the results.

Tests have been added accordingly. The backend version is now 0.9.0.

comments_data.body:
We had a conversation about this on the CHAOSS mailing list.

The idea is to maintain the event data collection as a regular part of
Perceval and deactivate it by default.
Managing it as a separate branch increases the overhead for keeping it in
sync with the overall development.
Keeping it separate also has the danger that the feature will not be
maintained at all and all the work was for nothing.
the compromise is to include it in the master branch development and simply
deactivate it by default, but anyone who wants to use it can do so.

>> Regarding the issue events, I agree with Valerio, in that, they will make
>> fetching data inefficient. Hence, I don't see this change getting merged
>> with grimoirelab-perceval's master branch. The sheer number of events per
>> issue as well as the extra API calls become exponentially more time
>> consuming for larger repositories. The obvious advantage for smaller
>> repositories would be access to the extra events information. Maybe if
>> GitHub finds some way to add more information to the main issue url
>> (<api_url>/issues/<issue_num>), that could be useful. For now though, issue
>> metrics would probably require working on the separate branch :( Open for
>> any good ideas though!
```

```
On Tue, Aug 20, 2019 at 7:31 PM Georg Link <linkgeorg at gmail.com> wrote:

> Aniruddha,
>
> Thank you for the reasoned thoughts on the subject. I need a bit more
> information to form my own opinion.
>
> 1) "sheer number of events per issue" - how many are we talking about on
> average or what is the median?
>
> 2) "extra API calls" - how many more calls are needed? One extra call per
> event; per issue; per ___?
>
> 3) "API calls become exponentially more time consuming for larger
> repositories" - I assume you have done some tests. What did you find for
> small, medium, and large repository?
>
> 4) "obvious advantage ... would be to access the extra events information"
> - What information is this? I'm not familiar with the API, so I don't know
> what specifically we gain.
>
> 5) "if GitHub finds some way to add more information" - Again, I'm not an
> expert on the GitHub API. Have you explored the GraphQL interface for
> retrieving this information?
>
> I believe if we get data for the above questions, then we can make an
> informed decision on whether it is worth integrating this feature or not.
>
> My biggest concern with having a separate branch is that it will be out of
> date very soon and unless we upstream the feature into the master branch,
> it will become useless and your work will be lost to us.
> What is your opinion on including the "extra events" as an optional
> feature that users can activate when needed but by default does not slow
> down data collection as it is now.
>
> Best,
> Georg
```

```
Hi Georg. Thanks for your queries.

Though I don't think I have the answer to all of your questions, I'll try
my best!

1. I don't have an exact number, but events include everything from
re-opening and closing to referencing, tagging, assigning, etc, and this
can be a very large number for active projects. More info can be found here
<https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/events/>.
2. I'm not too sure about this one, but for each issue, you have to
generally fetch the following (maybe Valerio can help you out with the
specifics):
- the general information for that issue
- the events
- comments information
- reactions
- comment reactions
- assignees data
3. No, I have not run any tests. Fetching so much information would add up
to a lot more API calls for large repositories
4. When you had asked this question, I thought you were asking about the
advantage of fetching events. I meant that the extra events information can
help a lot, since it gives a better picture of how often issues are
updated, rather than the updated_at field, which just gives the date of the
last update.
5. So, Perceval tries to fetch as much information as possible in the least
number of API calls. Most useful information is present on the url
<api_url>/issues/<issue_num>. If GitHub adds events information to this, it
would be better, since it would reduce the number of calls made.

My biggest concern with having a separate branch is that it will be out of
date very soon and unless we upstream the feature into the master branch,
it will become useless and your work will be lost to us.
Yes, that is a concern.

What is your opinion on including the "extra events" as an optional feature
that users can activate when needed but by default does not slow down data
collection as it is now.
That seems to be a good idea. May be we can ask Valerio if he would like
this to be added to Perceval as an option.
```

Before including the events as optional parameter, we may want to explore other alternatives @sduenas . They aim at keeping coherence with the other backends (i.e., fetching always the same data from a given data source).

The endpoint [events](https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/#events) is really basic and it doesn't seem to include parameters to retrieve a subset of events types or after/since a given date. Thus, we could contact the GitHub support and ask to include these parameters. If this request is accepted, we could include a limited set of events when fetching GItHub issues (taking into account @Polaris000 needs) .

As mentioned by @Polaris000, fetching issue events is highly inefficient and would affect the overall fetching process due to token consumption. Furthermore, for every issue updated, Perceval will retrieve the same events over and over. Under these conditions, it would be probably better to create a new category (events) and fetch [all issues events for a repository](https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/#list-issue-events-for-a-repository) 

WDYT @sduenas ?
I don't know what all you have tried. Would it be more efficient to ask for the data using the GraphQL interface, instead of the REST API?

We evaluated graphql time ago (https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/issues/160), but at the end we discard it.
It could be a nice experiment, maybe as a specific backend.
Thanks for the background. Any particular reason why GraphQL was dismissed?

user_data.name: Georg J.P. Link
user_data.bio: Director of Sales at Bitergia; Cofounder, Governing Board Member, and Maintainer of CHAOSS; Husband; Board Game enthusiast (he/him)

organizations.description: Concerned with the fragile state and future of highly-used and impactful open source projects? Join us.

comments_data.body:
Probably it was too early to integrate it. The limitations found were the following:

- GraphQL requires to be explicit about the fields returned by a query (there is nothing similar to SELECT * in SQL), so in some cases we could have pretty long queries.

- It doesn't seem possible to retrieve nested paginated data in a single query. For instance, issues are generally paginated and some of them can have paginated comments. In this case, two queries should be written to deal with the pagination on issues and comments (as similarly done with REST API calls).

Interesting, thank you.

>

data.title: [feature-request] Fetch events for issues
data.body:
Apart from the information fetched for issues (`<api_url>/issues/<issue_num>`), it may be a good idea to also fetch event information, or atleast the last re-open event for issues (`<api_url>/issues/<issue_num>/events`). 
Apart from the `created_at`, `closed_at` and `updated_at` fields, there could be an `events` field added to the issue data Perceval fetches.

Though I couldn't find any call to the `events` url in the github backend module, please let me know if this feature already exists.

Currently, when reopened issues are fetched by Perceval, the `status` field is `open` but there is a `closed_by` field as well. That could be one way to tell which issues were reopened, but how do you find the date of reopening?

Thanks in advance @valeriocos , @sduenas!

data.title: [backend] Include summary of fetch executions
data.body:
This PR allows to calculate and return the summary of fetch executions. By default, it includes the last
UUID generated, number of items fetched, skipped and their sum, plus the min, max and last updated_on times. Furthermore, for backends using offsets, the corresponding summary contains the min and max offsets retrieved. Finally, the summary also includes some extra fields, which can be used by any backend to include fetch-specific information.

The summary is sent to `stderr` at the end of any fetch or fetch_from_archive execution.

Tests have been added accordingly. The backend version is now 0.9.0.

To live-test `BackendItemsGenerator`, the function `run` should be modified in the following way:
```
def run(self):
    """Fetch and write items.

    This method runs the backend to fetch the items from the given
    origin. Items are converted to JSON objects and written to the
    defined output.

    If `fetch-archive` parameter was given as an argument during
    the inizialization of the instance, the items will be retrieved
    using the archive manager.
    """
    backend_args = vars(self.parsed_args)
    category = backend_args.pop('category', None)
    filter_classified = backend_args.pop('filter_classified', False)
    archived_since = backend_args.pop('archived_since', None)

    fetch_archive = False
    if self.archive_manager and self.parsed_args.fetch_archive:
        fetch_archive = True

    big = BackendItemsGenerator(self.BACKEND, backend_args, category, filter_classified,
                                self.archive_manager, archived_since, fetch_archive)

    try:
        for item in big.items():
            if self.json_line:
                obj = json.dumps(item, separators=(',', ':'), sort_keys=True)
            else:
                obj = json.dumps(item, indent=4, sort_keys=True)
            self.outfile.write(obj)
            self.outfile.write('\n')
            
        res = big.results()
    except IOError as e:
        raise RuntimeError(str(e))
    except Exception as e:
        raise RuntimeError(str(e))
```

def run(self):

data.title: [backend] Add search fields in metadata items - replaces #560
data.body:
This code enhances the metadata information with a set of search fields, which simplify query operations and avoid the manual inspections of the Perceval items.

These fields are added to the item metadata information in the search_fields attribute. By default, search_fields contains the id of the item ('item_id': item_id_value), obtained via the metadata_id method). However each backend can set extra search fields using the dict EXTRA_SEARCH_FIELDS. An example of EXTRA_SEARCH_FIELDS is provided below:

       {
          'project_id': ['fields', 'project', 'id'],
          'project_key': ['fields', 'project', 'key'],
          'project_name': ['fields', 'project', 'name']
       }
Each key in the dict is a search field to be included in the item metadata information, while the corresponding value is a list that stores the "path" of the search field value within the item.

Tests have been added accordingly.
The backend version is set to 0.10.0.

This PR replaces https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/pull/560 to simplify the reviewing

data.title: [backend] Add support for blacklisting items
data.body:
This PR extends Perceval to support the blacklisting of remote items. In a nutshell,the Namedtuple OriginUniqueField is defined to model the origin unique field (composed of a `name` and `type`). The OriginUniqueField is defined by each backend and used by the method `_skip_item` to filter
out the blacklisted items.

To showcase this approach, the github and git backends have been modified.

data.title: [backend] Add support for blacklisting items - v3
data.body:
This PR extends Perceval to support the blacklisting of remote items. In a nutshell, the Namedtuple OriginUniqueField is defined to model the origin unique field (composed of a name and type). The OriginUniqueField can be defined in the specific backend and used by the method _skip_item to filter out the blacklisted items.

Gitlab, Jenkins and Gerrit have been updated to use this new feature. Their tests have been updated accordingly.

The signature of the class `BackendCommandArgumentParser` has changed to accept as first parameter the backend object instead its categories. Tests and backends have been updated accordingly.

This PR is the follow up of https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/pull/575

data.title: [gitlab] Set extra HTTP retry status from backend
data.body:
This code allows to set from the backend/command line which HTTP status should be retried before raising a HTTP error. By default such status are 500 and 502, they complete the ones already defined in the HttpClient class (i.e., 413, 429, 503).

An example of how to set the retry status from command line is provided below:
```
perceval gitlab coldnight ci-test
--category merge_request
-t xxx
--sleep-for-rate
--extra-retry-status 500 502 503
```

Backend version is set to 0.11.0.
Tests have been added accordingly.

Signed-off-by: Valerio Cosentino <valcos@bitergia.com>

data.title: Perceval github with --fetch-archive (when there is no archive yet) fails
data.body:
I want to execute `perceval github` on some repo periodically. I don't want it to redo its full analysis every time. This seems to work OK when running without `--from-archive` for the first time and then subsequent runs can use `--from-archive` flag (to save time processing data already processed), but when I try to run with `--from-archive` when perceval was never run before:

`perceval github --category repository LF-Engineering sync-data-sources -t  xyz --fetch-archive --sleep-for-rate`:
```
[2019-11-09 13:34:43,582] - Sir Perceval is on his quest.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/backend.py", line 609, in run
    self._log_summary(big.summary)
  File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/backend.py", line 662, in _log_summary
    'total': summary.total,
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'total'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/perceval", line 6, in <module>
    exec(compile(open(__file__).read(), __file__, 'exec'))
  File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/bin/perceval", line 157, in <module>
    main()
  File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/bin/perceval", line 103, in main
    cmd.run()
  File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/backend.py", line 613, in run
    raise RuntimeError(str(e))
RuntimeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'total'
```

Is there a way to run a single `perceval` command that will figure out if there is data already and either get all data from scratch (when there is no data yet) or just continue from where it left the last time?

Same for all other data sources? Is there any generic option to handle that? I see that `perceval git` has `--latest-items` flag, how about other data sources? Do I have to run help on every single one of them and try to figure out what is the "resume" flag name for each?

BTW: `perceval datasource` lists data source command-line options, but nothing more, I have to guess by name what all those options do....is there any documentation that describes each data source all options - what they do?

user_data.name: Łukasz Gryglicki
user_data.bio:
Senior Developer @cncf, @linuxfoundation, @kubernetes
Interested in Go, Kubernetes, Helm, C, Ruby, RoR, Python, Rust, SQL, JavaScript, PHP, C++, Assembly

organizations.description: Sustaining and integrating open source technologies to orchestrate containers as part of a microservices architecture

comments_data.body:
BTW: is `--fetch-archive` actually doing what I think it does?
My understanding is that it fetches whatever was already processed from its SQLite archives database *and then fetches new GitHub data for newer activity*, right?

user_data.name: Łukasz Gryglicki
user_data.bio:
Senior Developer @cncf, @linuxfoundation, @kubernetes
Interested in Go, Kubernetes, Helm, C, Ruby, RoR, Python, Rust, SQL, JavaScript, PHP, C++, Assembly

organizations.description: Sustaining and integrating open source technologies to orchestrate containers as part of a microservices architecture

comments_data.body: cc @valeriocos @sduenas

user_data.name: Łukasz Gryglicki
user_data.bio:
Senior Developer @cncf, @linuxfoundation, @kubernetes
Interested in Go, Kubernetes, Helm, C, Ruby, RoR, Python, Rust, SQL, JavaScript, PHP, C++, Assembly

organizations.description: Sustaining and integrating open source technologies to orchestrate containers as part of a microservices architecture

comments_data.body:
The conclusion is that I can resume `perceval git` during the next run (so it only fetches new data since then) via `--latest-items` flag - this works.

But for GitHub `perceval github` there is no such flag, the closest thing I’ve found is `--fetch-archive` but this behaves like this:
My local perceval version (older) receives nothing when run with this flag for the first time, the newest version panics/errors in this case.

Running `perceval github` without this flag gets all data, but always processes all data from repo history, it doesn’t resume during the subsequent runs, so there is no way to let it fetch most data once and then only update daily for instance.

If after fetching all data without `--from-archive` I call `perceval github` with `--fetch-archive` flag - it will only fetch the data from last run, even if new data were added on GitHub since then (so it seems to only read data from disk and nothing more).

There is also a flag `--from-date`, but how can I know what is the last date that I have data for? 

Probably I can run in 2 approaches:
1 = FULL which will attempt to collect all data for all endpoints in all data sources without any resuming/caching/archives.

2 Then (say next day) with special flag START_DATE that will be passed to all endpoints. But in this case, if anything failed during the first (1) FULL run, the `FROM_DATE` run will never fix that.

Why the `perceval` doesn’t have a flag that will just read its own last output for given repo (it is saved in `~/.perceval`) and then automatically continue from there?

user_data.name: Łukasz Gryglicki
user_data.bio:
Senior Developer @cncf, @linuxfoundation, @kubernetes
Interested in Go, Kubernetes, Helm, C, Ruby, RoR, Python, Rust, SQL, JavaScript, PHP, C++, Assembly

organizations.description: Sustaining and integrating open source technologies to orchestrate containers as part of a microservices architecture

comments_data.body:
Perceval doesn't have that feature but in the case of Git. The archive is only conceived for testing purposes and not as a source of truth.
Perceval doesn't resume because it lets others to decide whether the downloaded data was valid or not. If you need something to do this work, use Arthur.

The only exception we have is with git due to how it works internally returning data when `git log` is called. It's possible that you don't get all the items added after a certain date.
OK, I've used `p2o.py` instead, it uses `ES` when running multiple times.

comments_data.body:
@lukaszgryglicki, I guess the group doesn't have enabled the permission to download archives. We experienced the same issue with another group, the solution was to ask the group's owner to enable that permission. More details at:
- https://beta.groups.io/g/api/topic/enable_download_archives/34544765?p=,,,20,0,0,0::recentpostdate%2Fsticky,,,20,2,0,34544765
- https://groups.io/g/GroupManagersForum/topic/39414187#21350

To be sure that the error is on the group's configuration, I executed the command `perceval groupsio hyperledger -e valcos@bitergia.com -p xxxx` and got the same error as you. By inspecting the response returned at: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/perceval/backends/core/groupsio.py#L237, I see this value:
`b'{"object":"error","type":"inadequate_permissions","extra":""}\n'`. This error is coherent with the initial guess and with what reported at: https://groups.io/api#download-archives.

The same perceval command works fine for another group, for instance `perceval groupsio OPNFV -e valcos@bitergia.com -p xxxx`

Hope this helps, please close this issue if the answer above solves your problem, thanks!
OK thanks for the info, that wasn't obvious from the error returned.

data.title: [github] Handle `None` requested reviewers
data.body:
This PR addressed https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/issues/590. Thus it handles `None` values for requested reviewers. Before accessing the login attribute, a condition checks that the reviewer is not None and the `login` attribute exists.

An example of this behaviour is visible at: hyperledger/sawtooth-core#93, where the last requested
reviewer (on the right side) is None, and only a yellow circle (without name) is shown on the web page.

Backend version is now 0.24.1
Tests have been added accordingly.

This PR includes also a minor fix wrt variable names used in some github tests.

data.title: [jenkins] Handle workflow multibranch job builds
data.body:
This code allows to process workflow multibranches job, which include nested jobs and their corresponding builds.

Since the API doesn't offer an endpoint to retrieve workflow jobs, the backend leverages on the class type of the job to process it accordingly. Thus, if the class type is `WorkflowMultiBranchProject`, the nested jobs are retrieved one by one and their builds obtained. Otherwise the logic to process the job is left as it was.

Tests have been added accordingly.
Backend version is now 0.15.0

data.title: Investigate support for Jenkins pipelines
data.body:
After checking the issue #591 with @sduenas, it seems that Jenkins may return jobs of different types. For instance, here https://jenkins.zowe.org/, the jobs below are related to  multibranch pipelines.

- https://jenkins.zowe.org/job/zowe-dockerimage-test/ (not configured)
- https://jenkins.zowe.org/job/zowe-docs-site/ (a job inside)
- https://jenkins.zowe.org/job/zowe-helloworld-jjb/ (not configured)

The idea is check whether the API allows to retrieve builds inside multibranch pipelines.

comments_data.body: This was already fixed by #597

data.title: [discourse] Pass credentials via headers
data.body:
This code changes the way the credentials are passed due to [a recent change](https://meta.discourse.org/t/discourse-api-documentation/22706) in the Discourse API. Now, the credentials, defined as `api_token` and `api_username` are defined in the headers (and not as request params).

Tests have been updated accordingly.

Backend version is now 0.12.0.

Is there any alternative/workaround of using Bitbucket with Grimoire?

> Is there any alternative/workaround of using Bitbucket with Grimoire?

If you're interested only in git repos, you can easily use the git backend. If you're interested in pull requests, they are not supported yet, a Perceval backend would be needed.

> If you're interested only in git repos, you can easily use the git  backend.

Does this mean interested on using Perceval with Bitbucket without the PRs?
If so, how can we specify the authentication?
Thanks!

> Does this mean interested on using Perceval with Bitbucket without the PRs?

Yes.

> If so, how can we specify the authentication?

If the repository is public, nothing to do, since Perceval uses git for accessing it, and there are no calls too the Bitbucket API. If the repository is private, if you already have your account configured to access it, it should just work, because Perceval is basically running git clone. Please, let us know if it does not work in either of these cases: to be honest, my experience with analyzing Bitbucket is not that large.
I'd like to contribute a bitbucket interface for this project. bitbucket has similar APIs to github.

That would be great! Please take as reference [github.py](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/perceval/backends/core/github.py) and [gitlab.py](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/perceval/backends/core/gitlab.py) as reference.
Hi @aaronnickovich, thank you for your interest! If you need some help don't hesitate to ping us! Feel also free to share your branch and we can work on it together!

I have a question for the community. I've been working on a bitbucket implementation and the public domain bitbucket uses an API V2. However, enterprise bitbucket is typically using the v1 API. They are very different. 
Would anyone like to help suggest if Perceval should have a bitbucketv1 and a bitbucket, or would it be better to do a bitbucket interface with something like an --api-version flag that will select the api version? I believe there is a deprecation warning issued by bitbucket so I'm worried about maintanence as well. Please look at my branch.

From my point of view, having a --api (or similar) flag would be the way to go (even if we start with a single API supported). This happens not only in Bitbucket, we have other data sources with different APIs too.

Maybe a reason for not having that flag would be that it can be automagically inferred from a simple query to the API which version it is implementing.

> From my point of view, having a --api (or similar) flag would be the way to go (even if we start with a single API supported). This happens not only in Bitbucket, we have other data sources with different APIs too.
>
> Maybe a reason for not having that flag would be that it can be automagically inferred from a simple query to the API which version it is implementing.

These data sources you refer to appear to be minor changes in how to fetch something with a slightly different server version. For instance, mediawiki and gerrit. When I talk about bitbucket APIs, it's actually two different products offered by Atlassian:
**Bitbucket Server**: [https://docs.atlassian.com/bitbucket-server/rest/6.7.1/bitbucket-rest.html](url)
**Bitbucket Cloud**: [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource](url)

Bitbucket SERVER has different versions like 5.10 and 6.7, and the rest interface do not seem to change much even between the major versions.

The cloud vs server is, however, so vast it's like trying to combine github and gitlab together. It'd honestly be similar to switch between the two classes like this:
if( --api == 1.0):
use github.backend and github.client
elif (--api == 2.0):
use gitlab.backend and gitlab.client

What I know absolutely today is this: 
bitbucket.org (CLOUD) === API v2
bitbucket.{some-enterprise.com} (SERVER) == API v1

What I don't know now or in future plans:
bitbucket.{some-enterprise.com} == v2

To begin I thought perceval should have a "bitbucket" data collection implementation for both cloud and server, but it's so different that it's not very nice using if, else to separate them out.

With respect to integration with SirMordred, auto-magic is nice to have.

Does data have the same fields and structure depending which version you use? Hi @sduenas, No the input and output of each have about as much in common as gitlab and github. It's actually bitbucket server and bitbucket cloud which look like 2 different product offerings. The field for 'name' in cloud is 'slug' in bitbucket server. Same goes for 'uuid' vs 'id', respectively. Cloud offers a CI/CD build tool and an issues page which are missing from the server implementation. I haven't worked on ELK but I understand it adds some metadata. I think I see where you're going with this. If these two produce different data, then it should be treated as a different perceval agent.

Hey, I had a doubt,
How can I test for a new backend from the command line?
Also is there any gitter chat or any other platform to connect and ask a few more doubts if needed.

HI @sarthak0906,

You can install Perceval with the new backend in a virtual env (see details below) or test it from pycharm (you should create a configuration and pass the params, details about how to run Perceval with Pycharm can be found here: https://github.com/inishchith/chaoss-microtasks/tree/master/microtask-1, an example of configuration is at [1])
```
python3 -m venv /tmp/mytest
cd /tmp/mytest
source bin/activate
cd <perceval-path>
pip install . -e    
perceval --help <--- check that perceval has been installed
```

[1]
![captura_141](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6515067/69480861-8f4f7600-0e0b-11ea-9f21-bddef48f49c3.png)


We can use the IRC channel (`#chaoss-community irc channel in FreeNode.net` , more info at https://chaoss.community/participate/) or set up a Skype/Google Hangouts call. When would you like to meet?

Hi @sarthak0906 and @valeriocos, 
I actually just started adding tests for one of the backends this week. I figured out a test workflow for myself that works for me. I like to run tests with code coverage reports to see what areas I'm missing in the test cases so I'm not making redundant tests.

Once you have run the steps mentioned by valeriocos above to setup your environment:
```
python3 -m venv /tmp/mytest
cd /tmp/mytest
source bin/activate
cd <perceval-path>
pip install . -e    
perceval --help <--- check that perceval has been installed
```

I like to run tests like this using cli:
```
pip3 install pytest-cov coverage
cd <base_directory_of_perceval>/perceval/backends/core
py.test ../../../tests/test_bitbucketserver.py --cov=perceval.backends.core.bitbucketserver --cov-report html --cov-report term-missing
firefox ./htmlcov/index.html          <---- view graphical test coverage 
```

the test coverage outputs an index.html where I can browse for covered, missed, or skipped code like this: https://nedbatchelder.com/files/sample_coverage_html/index.html

Nice pointer @aaronnickovich!

I use just `coverage` and execute it twice:
- `coverage/__main__.py run run_tests.py --source=perceval` to generate the `.coverage` file
- `coverage/__main__.py report -m` to get a textual output from `.coverage` as the one below

```

I'm still trying to complete the task before I go on to test it, 
but it definitely is very helpful and will remember it

data.title: commits count
data.body:
Hi,
I noticed a difference between commits mentioned on GitHub and when I fetched through perceval (always more). Why is that?

Thanks in advance.

comments_data.body:
Could this explain it?:

> "The statistics exposed by the API match the statistics shown by different repository graphs. [...] All statistics exclude merge commits."
> (From ["Statistics" in GitHub API docs](https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/statistics/#statistics-exclude-some-types-of-commits)).

If that's not the case, please provide an specific example.
Thanks. "All statistics exclude merge commits". So perceval fetches these commits too?
Yes. Perceval fetches all commits in the repository, except that a branch is specified, in which case only commits in that branch are fetched.
Thanks a lot.

Thanks to you for caring!

Can we close this issue then?
Yeah. I think this is already resolved.
By the way, for completion, GitHub only shows the number of commits from `master` (or the default branch), not from other branches.

data.title: Jira backend is not working for the correct email/password pair (only some Jira URLs not all)
data.body:
Command: `p2o.py --enrich --index sds-o-ran-documentation-jira-raw --index-enrich sds-o-ran-documentation-jira -e (redacted) --db-host mariadb.mariadb --db-sortinghat sortinghat --db-user sortinghat --db-password (redacted) jira https://jira.o-ran-sc.org --project DOC -u (redacted) -p (redacted) --no-archive --verify False`: ``` 2019-12-05 07:34:19,788 [jira] Incremental from: None for https://jira.o-ran-sc.org 2019-12-05 07:34:19,789 Looking for issues at site 'https://jira.o-ran-sc.org', in project 'DOC' and updated from '1970-01-01 00:00:00+00:00' 2019-12-05 07:34:19,845 Error feeding raw from jira (https://jira.o-ran-sc.org): 401 Client Error: for url: https://jira.o-ran-sc.org/rest/api/2/field Traceback (most recent call last): File "/repos/grimoirelab-elk/grimoire_elk/elk.py", line 228, in feed_backend ocean_backend.feed(**params) File "/repos/grimoirelab-elk/grimoire_elk/raw/elastic.py", line 234, in feed self.feed_items(items) File "/repos/grimoirelab-elk/grimoire_elk/raw/elastic.py", line 250, in feed_items for item in items: File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/backend.py", line 215, in fetch for item in self.fetch_items(category, **kwargs): File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/backends/core/jira.py", line 161, in fetch_items fields = json.loads(self.client.get_fields()) File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/backends/core/jira.py", line 354, in get_fields req = self.fetch(url) File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/client.py", line 133, in fetch response = self._fetch_from_remote(url, payload, headers, method, stream, verify, auth) File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/client.py", line 176, in _fetch_from_remote raise e File "/repos/grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/client.py", line 169, in _fetch_from_remote response.raise_for_status() File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/requests/models.py", line 940, in raise_for_status raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self) requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 401 Client Error: for url: https://jira.o-ran-sc.org/rest/api/2/field 2019-12-05 07:34:19,846 [jira] Done collection for https://jira.o-ran-sc.org 2019-12-05 07:34:19,846 Backend feed completed 2019-12-05 07:34:19,913 [jira] 0 items inserted for Jira 2019-12-05 07:34:19,914 [jira] Done enrichment for https://jira.o-ran-sc.org 2019-12-05 07:34:19,914 Enrich backend completed 2019-12-05 07:34:19,914 Finished in 0.00 min ``` I was debugging this a lot and those credentails are 100% sure OK. I've taken two Jira instances, one is for `Hyperledger` and another one is for `O-RAN`. In both Jiras I have the same username say `user1` and passowrd say `password1`. Both Jiras authenticating correctly from UI using those credentials. I've tracked this down to `self.session.get(url,...)` - it doesn't work for `O-RAN` and works for `Hyperledger`. But if I replace code with `requests.Session().get(url, ...)` it works for both (this is the first query that just gets a list of fields from the REST API endpoint: `/rest/api/2/field`) Now the difference is that the `self.session` object has `self.session.auth` containing `user1, password1` pair while `requests.Session()` executes call without auth headers. My clue is that Jira for `O-RAN` is not supporting auth header while Jira for `Hyperledger` does. This is the case indeed, checked by `curl`: For `hyperledger` credentials work: `curl --user user1:password1 https://jira.hyperledger.org/rest/api/2/field`. For `O-RAN` they’re not working: `curl --user user1:password1 https://jira.o-ran-sc.org/rest/api/2/field` Both those credentials work OK from the Jira UI. Seems like O-RAN Jira is passing those credentials in some other way than auth headers, and this is not supported by Grimoire backend... The only difference I can see from the UI is that `Hyperledger` *is not* using SSO/LFID and `O-RAN` is using SSO/LFID. How can I process Jira data by Perceval backend when jira uses SSO/LFID? --------------------- One more thing, error message is very very cryptic in this case and required python debugging using `pdb` and modifying sources, adding just a single line makes the problem obvious, this is also the case in many more grimoire backend - they return crypting 40X Client or Server errors and nothing more - no one will have any idea why they fail... If you just edit `grimoirelab-perceval/perceval/client.py` file, `def _fetch_from_remote(self, url, payload, headers, method, stream, verify, auth):` function and just add `+` this code `print(response.text)`: ``` except Exception as e: + print(response.text) ``` You will get the exact cause of failure: ``` (...) Unauthorized (401) (...)

Encountered a "401 - Unauthorized" error while loading this page.

Basic Authentication Failure - Reason : AUTHENTICATED_FAILED

(...) ```

When I run Grimoirelab (0.2.36, built myself as full-3p including third-party tools), I get errors about issues and merge requests. The error looks like this:

```
2020-01-10 15:35:43,145 - grimoire_elk.elk - ERROR - Error feeding raw from gitlab (https://gitlab.my-enterprise.com/my-project/my-repo.git): 404 Client Error: Not Found for url: https://gitlab.my-enterprise.com/api/v4/projects/my-project%2Fmy-repo.git/issues?updated_after=1970-01-01T00%3A00%3A00%2B00%3A00&sort=asc&per_page=100&order_by=updated_at&state=all

    self.feed_items(items)

    for item in items:

    for item in self.fetch_items(category, **kwargs):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/perceval/backends/core/gitlab.py", line 259, in __fetch_issues
    for raw_issues in issues_groups:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/perceval/backends/core/gitlab.py", line 644, in fetch_items
    response = self.fetch(url_next, payload=payload)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/perceval/backends/core/gitlab.py", line 628, in fetch
    response = super().fetch(url, payload, headers, method, stream)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/perceval/client.py", line 132, in fetch
    response = self._fetch_from_remote(url, payload, headers, method, stream, verify, auth)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/perceval/client.py", line 173, in _fetch_from_remote
    raise e
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/perceval/client.py", line 168, in _fetch_from_remote
    response.raise_for_status()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/requests/models.py", line 940, in raise_for_status
    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 404 Client Error: Not Found for url: https://gitlab.my-enterprise.com/api/v4/projects/my-project%2Fmy-repo.git/issues?updated_after=1970-01-01T00%3A00%3A00%2B00%3A00&sort=asc&per_page=100&order_by=updated_at&state=all
```

What strikes me as potentially incorrect, is that the URL in the error message contains both slashes ('/') and escaped slashes ('%2F'). I'm aware of the need to type '%2F' in my projects json when there are more directories, but my understanding was that in this case the way I typed it should be correct. Is this a bug or am I doing something wrong? Thanks!!

data.body:
Hello,

I've made a test installation with docker and so far so good. The ```git``` and ```github``` backends are working.
Now I tried to add data from Twitter.

I've created the Twitter bearer token using [this script](https://gist.github.com/valeriocos/7d4d28f72f53fbce49f1512ba77ef5f6) edited the credentials.cfg and added the twitter token like so. _please note that the access_token has a % symbol_

```
[github]
api-token = [redacted]
[twitter]
token_type = bearer
access_token  = [redacted]
```
and the projects.json
```
[...]
        ],
        "twitter": [
        "MYTWITTERHANDLE"
        ]
[...]
```

As soon as I start the docker-compose file this error appears:
```
grimoire       | Starting SirMordred to build a GrimoireLab dashboard
grimoire       | This will usually take a while...
grimoire       | Traceback (most recent call last):

I tried to put the twitter access token under single and double quotes without success.

What else can I try?
